lexUnit.name: prone.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: having a tendency or inclination

sentence.text: Contrary to what is often supposed , the Dutch were scarcely less prone to employ political means to promote their economic position than was the France of Louis XIV and Colbert .
Flat ground and the slopes of the Marne valley are particularly prone to frost .
Some colours , particularly shades of red , are prone to fading so it is important to use the right products .
The Secretary of State is also prone to make pronouncements which can be highly relevant , especially on appeal .
Every believer is prone to doubt , but some are more prone to one kind and some to another .
So it is misleading to suggest , as many psychologists and sociobiologists are prone to do , that these mechanisms are necessarily the prime mechanism affecting awareness and action .
Young Killifish are prone to velvet disease and Gold Australe are not exempt from this problem .
The registration procedure is as prone to human error as any other system of recording .
Tired , malnourished people are prone to infection .
He is also prone to jump to conclusions .
Piper knows Benn is prone to run out of gas if he ca n't get through in the early rounds .
Westerners are equally prone to misunderstand because of our cultural distancing .
Students are prone to explain undesirable features of a system in terms of its most salient characteristics .
Formerly he had been prone to pessimism , full of gloomy prognoses about over-population and wars , which would prevent mankind from ever fulfilling its dream of colonising other planets .

Elderly people become more prone to falls often because of arthritic joints or dizziness , are vulnerable to pedestrian accidents perhaps due to lessened acuity in sight and hearing and at risk to the hazards of fire .
Along with the good humour , it is a reminder that Young 's personality , like his music , is prone to abrupt changes of mood and temperament .
In a boring , repetitive task these subjects are not only prone to occasional failures to respond , but their " good " responses are also impaired .
People who are depressed generally are prone to committing suicide .
I was a teenager , prone to the daftness that goes with that age group , and knew no better .
Modern gliders are more prone to swinging than older aircraft and it is a little more difficult to keep the wings level , so do n't relax until the glider has come to rest .
As with any chemical treatment , colour can cause hair to become dry and prone to splitting , especially on the ends .

To cover her confusion she enquired after the latest entertaining village gossip from Lucy , who was prone to whiling away hours at the ante-natal clinic in deep conversation with fellow village wives .
` I 've heard of people being accident prone , " Harris observed after a while , ` but you seem to he murder prone , Melissa . "
In a curious way , women are probably more prone than men to changes of mood , but are more able to manipulate them .
